abstract.text: An object that applies a gravity-like force to all of its associated dynamic items.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The magnitude and direction of the gravity force are configurable and are applied equally to all associated items. Use this behavior to modify the position of views and other dynamic items in your app’s interface.
You specify the magnitude and direction of the gravity force as a two-dimensional vector in the reference view’s coordinate system. A value of
imparts the standard UIKit gravity, which corresponds to an acceleration of 1000 points / second² in the direction of the given axis. The default vector in the
), which causes items to accelerate downward along the positive y axis. If you prefer to set the vector
separately, you can do so using the corresponding properties.
If you want a gravitational force that takes the mass of each object into account, use a
object instead. Field behaviors support both linear and radial gravitation fields and take the mass of an object into account, resulting in different amounts of force applied to each object.
If you want to influence a gravity behavior at each step of a dynamic animation, assign an appropriate block to the inherited
property. Use your block to make any needed changes to the dynamic items associated with the gravity behavior.

content.text: Applying a Gravity Behavior to an Item

inlineContent.text: To apply a gravity behavior to one or more dynamic items, do the following:
method, passing in the items you want associated with the behavior. Use the
method to add items after initialization. For more information about dynamic items, see
Enable the gravity behavior by adding it to your
method. (Do not add more than one gravity behavior to an animator.)

The gravity behavior derives its coordinate system from the reference view of its associated dynamic animator object. For more information about the dynamic animator and the reference coordinate system, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A relationship between two dynamic items, or between a dynamic item and an anchor point.
An object that confers to a specified array of dynamic items the ability to engage in collisions with each other and with the behavior’s specified boundaries.
An object that provides physics-related capabilities and animations for its dynamic items, and provides the context for those animations.
Adds a dynamic behavior to a dynamic animator.
An object that confers a behavioral configuration on one or more dynamic items, for their participation in 2D animation.
The block you want to execute during dynamic animation.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
An object that applies field-based physics to dynamic items.
An object that applies a gravity-like force to all of its associated dynamic items.
Associates the specified dynamic item with the gravity behavior.
The direction of the gravity vector, expressed in radians in the reference coordinate system.
The direction and magnitude of the gravitational force, expressed as a vector.
Initializes a gravity behavior with an array of dynamic items.
The set of dynamic items associated with the gravity behavior.
The magnitude of the gravity vector.
Removes the specified dynamic item from the gravity behavior.
Sets the angle and magnitude of the gravity vector for the behavior.
A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.
A spring-like behavior whose initial motion is damped over time so that the object settles at a specific point.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
